title: Richard Dewhurst Serif
content:
Hi there, can anyone enlighten me as to what this particular serif is? I'd also be interested in knowing what other serif fonts have that 'st' ligature, if that's the right term. Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121im_/http:/typophile.com/files/st_6403.jpg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [st.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/typophile.com/files/st_2.jpg) | 59.14 KB |
author: furryvision

comments.content: I think this is [Hoefler Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100010). There are quite a number of fonts that contains the st ligature. Someone here may help you with a list? ;^)
Thanks, that looks like the one! A couple of names of similar nice serifs with the 'st' ligature would be much appreciated. A list is perhaps above and beyond but if someone's feeling enthusiastic!

I think this looks like a version of Garamond, but I'm not sure which foundry. The R foot serif is not like the Adobe versions, because it sits flat on the baseline, but I can't seem to find one that seems identical in all details.

As for the ligatures like st and ct, most of the OpenType versions of classic serif families have them and some of the older (PS/TT) families do as well, usually when they are from the major foundries.

- Mike Yanega

Hmm, a drawback in searching only MyFonts. Good job Marten.

- Mike Yanega

But Mike, on the other hand you gave Furryvision a hint on fonts containing the st ligature. [Adobe Premier Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/cfusion/store/html/index.cfm?store=OLS-US&event=displayFontPackage&code=1737), [Baskerville 1757](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/baskerville1757.asp), [Exemplar](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_exemplar.html) and [Delicato](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/delicato.asp) is a few examples...
Thank you both. I'll pull my finger out and do some of my own searching. I actually have Hoefler so shows how poor my knowledge is!

Serif fonts with 'ct' and 'st' ligatures:

[Mrs Eaves](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/emigre/mrs_eaves_roman_ot/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_ss=3)  
 [Big Caslon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/carter_cone/big_caslon_cc/)  
 [Adobe Caslon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative_alliance/adobe_caslon_pro_regular/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=48&acs_ss=4)  
 [Adobe Garmond](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative_alliance/adobe_garamond_pro_regular/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=36&acs_ss=4) (ct only)  
 [Karmina](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/typetogether/karmina_regular/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=36&acs_ss=3)  
 [Athelas](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/typetogether/athelas_regular/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=36&acs_ss=3)  
 [ITC Galliard](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/itc/itc_galliard_pro_roman/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=36&acs_ss=3)  
 [LTC Village No. 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/lanston_type/ltc_village_no_2_pro/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=48&acs_ss=3)  
 [LTC Caslon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/lanston_type/ltc_caslon_pro/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_ss=3&acs_pt=36)  
 [LTC Garamont Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/lanston_type/ltc_garamont_text_roman_pro/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=48&acs_ss=3)  
 [LTC Cloister](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/lanston_type/ltc_cloister_pro/?sample_text=See%20ligatures%20below.&acs_pt=48&acs_ss=5)
that's very kind of you, thank you very much!

I'm sure Stephen's list is just a starting point. As I said earlier, most of the Open Type releases, especially of new serif families, will probably include these ligatures. For example Adobe's [Minion Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/type/browser/pdfs/MINP/MinionPro-Regular.pdf), [Garamond Premier Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/type/browser/pdfs/1737.pdf), [Arno Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/type/browser/pdfs/1739.pdf), [Brioso Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/type/browser/pdfs/BIOQ/BriosoPro-Regular.pdf), [Jenson Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/type/browser/pdfs/1716.pdf), [Warnock Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/store1.adobe.com/type/browser/pdfs/WARP/WarnockPro-Regular.pdf) and probably most of their other "Pro" releases all have st, ct and sp ligatures (although Garamond Pro has only the ct, as Stephen stated).

- Mike Yanega
A seemingly underused, but beautiful typeface, with both ct and st ligs is [FF Clifford](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022062121/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_clifford_ot/).
